The practice is parallel to the <a href="Judaeo-Christian">Judaeo-Christian</a> religious doctrine, as flaunting the <a href="Intimate%20parts%20in%20Islam">intimate body parts</a> is considered as forbidden in Islam. The interpretation was then absorbed to the Malay way of dressing and cultural perspective, this can be strongly witnessed upon the rule of <a href="Mansur%20Shah%20of%20Malacca">Mansur Shah of Malacca</a> in the 15th century, the sultan prohibited his female Muslim subjects in the public from wearing only a sarong from the bust downwards. Throughout the ages, The Malay Baju Kurung went into several reincarnation before assuming its current form. Due to the vastness of various Malay kingdoms in the <a href="Malay%20archipelago">archipelago</a>, local and distinct forms of the Baju Kurung design patterns can also be witnessed in the region, including Bengkulu, Kedah, Jambi, Johor-Riau, Pahang and Palembang.
The corresponding mode of Baju Kurung for men is known as "Baju Melayu". The upper part of the garment was made with the geometrical design almost similar with Baju Kurung and commonly paired with woven cloth known as the sarong. The pattern of the sarong may possessed a symbol of the person's marital status or the rank in the classical Malay society.
Other common classical Malay attire for men consists of a "baju" (shirt) or "tekua" (a type of a long sleeve shirt), "baju rompi" (vest), "kancing" (button), a small leg "celana" (trousers), a <a href="sarong">sarong</a> worn around the waist, "capal" (sandal), and a "tanjak" or "tengkolok" (<a href="headgear">headgear</a>); for the aristocrats, the "baju sikap" or "baju layang" (a type of coat) and "pending" (ornamental belt buckle) are also synonymous to be worn as a formal attire. It was also common for a "pendekar" (Malay warrior) to have a <a href="Kris">Kris</a> tucked into the front fold of sarong.
In contrast to Baju Melayu which continued to be worn as ceremonial dress only, Baju Kurung is worn daily throughout the year by a majority of Malay women. Sighting of female civil servants, professional workers and students wearing Baju Kurung is common in Malaysia and Brunei.
Festivals and celebrations.
The rise of <a href="Islam">Islam</a> managed to <a href="ethnogenesis">redefine</a> the <a href="Malayness">Malay identity</a> by the 15th century. Thus, resulting most of the Malay festivals and celebrations to run parallel with the <a href="Islamic%20calendar">Islamic calendar</a>, albeit deeply ingrained with a strong sense of <a href="Malayisation">Malay character</a>. The biannual <a href="Hari%20Raya">Hari Raya</a> (lit "the Great Day") observance of <a href="Aildifitri">Aildifitri</a> and <a href="Aidiladha">Aidiladha</a> are hailed as the grand celebrations universally across the Malay community. The two holidays are instrumental to commentate two major events and philosophy in the Islamic teaching and beliefs. The former signifies the triumph as a Muslim after a month of <a href="Fasting%20in%20Islam">fasting</a> and patience in <a href="Ramadan">Ramadan</a>, while the latter is to observe the sacrifice made by <a href="Ibrahim">Ibrahim</a> (Abraham) under the name of <a href="Allah">Allah</a>.
The "Raya" holidays usually commenced during the <a href="wikt%3Ahomecoming">homecoming</a> event known as <a href="Balik%20Kampung">Balik Kampung</a> or "Balik Raya" which occurred a few days before the festival. During the Hari Raya, the Malays would celebrated by performing the <a href="Eid%20prayers">Eid prayers</a>, holding a grand feast and visiting friends, relatives and neighbours. A visit to the grave of the departed loved ones is also essential, as a sign of respect, love and honour.
Other major liturgical and religious ceremonies celebrated by the Malays include <a href="Ramadhan">Ramadhan</a>, a month-long holy month devoted by daytime fasting and various religious activities; <a href="Maulidur%20Rasul">Maulidur Rasul</a>, a special grand procession to honour the birth of Prophet <a href="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>; <a href="Ashura">Ashura</a>, remembrance of <a href="Muharram">Muharram</a> where the Malays would solemnly prepared a special dish, known as "Bubur Ashura"; <a href="Nisfu%20Syaaban">Nisfu Syaaban</a>, the Mid-<a href="Sha%27ban">Sha'ban</a> observance, a special day of <a href="fasting">fasting</a> for forgiveness; <a href="Nuzul%20Quran">Nuzul Quran</a>, the first revelation of the <a href="Quran">Quran</a>; <a href="Israk%20dan%20Mikraj">Israk dan Mikraj</a>, the ascension Prophet Muhammed to the heavens and <a href="Awal%20Muharram">Awal Muharram</a>, the Islamic New Year; the latter three celebrations are usually observed by holding a special "sunat" prayers, religious lectures and Islamic discussions in the <a href="mosque">mosque</a>.
There are also a plethora of domestic regional cultural festivals and social events within different the Malay spheres. The coastal areas were historically known to observed the "Mandi Safar" or "Puja Pantai" ceremony, a purifying bath during the <a href="Islamic%20calendar">Islamic month</a> of <a href="Safar">Safar</a>, originally emulated from the ancient pre-Islamic Malay holy cleansing rituals; and "Pesta Menuai", a <a href="harvest%20festival">harvest festival</a> celebrated by the inland and agrarian Malay communities by traditional games, theatre, <a href="Joget">Joget</a> and other repertoire of dance-play. However, both of the practice is gradually extinct owing from various social and economic revolution engineered in the Malay community in the 20th century. Additionally, many Malays are also known to participate in the imperial celebrations to honour the royal courts of their respective kingdoms.
The Islamic features also strongly embroidered the Malay celebrations in the individual level, a juxtaposition bonded to the spiritual <a href="rite%20of%20passage">rite of passage</a> as a Muslim. The Malays would usually organised "kenduri", a religious ceremonial banquet to celebrate or to seek blessing for an event. There are several philosophical variations of kenduri, raging from "Doa Selamat" (asking for divine favour and protection), "Kesyukuran" (for thanksgiving and gratitude), "Melenggang Perut" (ceremonial massage for a mother who is pregnant with her first child), "Aqiqah" and "Cukur Jambul" (newborn ceremony, for celebrating a new life), "Bertindik" (the first piercing ceremony for a female child), "Khatam" (a graduation ceremony, after a child's first full-reading of the <a href="Quran">Quran</a>), "Khatan" (<a href="circumcision">circumcision</a>), "Kahwin" (<a href="wedding">wedding</a>), "Arwah" or "Tahlil" (prayers for a deceased person), among few. The event is usually organised by the family and was traditionally aided by the community in a social gathering known as "Rewang" or "Gotong-royong". During this ceremony, the whole family would be assisted by their neighbours and relatives, delegating various tasks raging from food preparations, venue management, logistic assembly and other technical control. Nevertheless, following the rise of <a href="urbanism">urbanism</a> in the contemporary Malay community, the practice of "Rewang/Gotong-Royong" is gradually superseded by hired-<a href="catering">caterer</a> services by the family.
Martial arts.
Silat and its variants can be found throughout the Malay world: the <a href="Malay%20peninsula">Malay peninsula</a> (including <a href="Singapore">Singapore</a>), the <a href="Riau%20Islands">Riau Islands</a>, <a href="Sumatra">Sumatra</a> and coastal areas of <a href="Borneo">Borneo</a>. Archaeological evidence reveals that, by the 6th century, formalised combat arts were being practised in the Malay peninsular and Sumatra. The earliest forms of Silat are believed to have been developed and used in the armed forces of the ancient Malay kingdoms of <a href="Langkasuka">Langkasuka</a> (2nd century) and Srivijaya (7th century).
The influence of the Malay sultanates of Malacca, <a href="Johor%20Sultanate">Johor</a>, <a href="Pattani%20Kingdom">Pattani</a> and <a href="Brunei%20Sultanate">Brunei</a> has contributed to the spread of this martial art in the Malay Archipelago. Through a complex maze of sea channels and river capillaries that facilitated exchange and trade throughout the region, Silat wound its way into the dense rainforest and up into the mountains. The legendary <a href="Laksamana">Laksamana</a> <a href="Hang%20Tuah">Hang Tuah</a> of Malacca is one of the most renowned "pesilat" (Silat practitioners) in history and even considered by some as the father of Malay silat. Since the classical era, <a href="Silat%20Melayu">Silat Melayu</a> underwent great diversification and formed what is today traditionally recognised as the source of Indonesian <a href="Pencak%20Silat">Pencak Silat</a> and other forms of Silat in Southeast Asia.
Apart from Silat, <a href="Tomoi">Tomoi</a> is also practised by Malays, mainly in the northern region of the Malay peninsula. It is a variant of <a href="Indochina">Indo-Chinese</a> forms of <a href="kickboxing">kickboxing</a> which is believed to have been spread in the Southeast Asian mainland since the time of <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Funan">Funan Empire</a> (68 AD).
Metal casting.
In the Malay society, classical <a href="metalworks">metalworks</a> assumed a role more than a mere instrumental tool. It serves as a testament of <a href="culture">culture</a>, cultivated by <a href="art">art</a>istic appreciation and <a href="religious">religious</a> symbol, molded by a craftsman who possessed a talent to redefined the essence of nature in the most ornamental manner. The artform has indeed received a long existence in the <a href="Malay%20World">Malay World</a>, observations made by the <a href="Arab%20people">Arabs</a> on the courts of <a href="Srivijaya">Srivijaya</a> narrated that about the abundance of golds in the <a href="Palembang">capital</a>, till the extend that the bars have to be ceremonially thrown into the <a href="estuary">estuary</a> in a daily basis. On the Chinese accounts, the area was occasionally hailed as "Jinzou", the <a href="gold">gold</a> coast. The zenith of Srivijaya also witnessed the arrivals of <a href="silver">silver</a> bought by the foreign merchants, which then spread to the members of Malay aristocracy.
Upon the turn of the 17th century, gold, silver, <a href="iron">iron</a> and <a href="brass">brass</a> have all been perfectly molded to become part and parcel to the Malay society. The era witnessed the works of metal received a critical royal patronage. A multitude of Malay metalworks manifested as evidence of this era, raging from a peculiar Malay dagger known as <a href="Keris">Keris</a> made of iron, down to the elaborate fine <a href="jewellery">jewellery</a> made from the splendor of gold and silver. For the Malay nobles during this period, the works of pending (ornamental <a href="Belt%20buckle">Belt buckle</a> embellished with <a href="precious%20stones">precious stones</a>), "keronsang" (brooch) and "cucuk sanggul" (hairpins) were staged to become among the most sought item of fashion. The era also hosted a number of other prominent items in the Malay regalia cast in gold, including ceremonial box, "Tepak sirih" (Betel container) and parts of Keris. The art of casting gold were predominantly done by <a href="repouss%C3%A9">repoussé</a> and <a href="Granulation%20%28process%29">granulation</a> techniques, in which the traditional methods can still be witnessed until today. In the contemporary era, the Malay gold jewels are mainly found in the form of anklets, bracelets, rings, necklaces, pendants and earrings.
For the Malay silverware, the works of silver are fairly known for its sophisticated and fine designs. It is usually crafted in the form of repousse, <a href="filigree">filigree</a> and <a href="Niello">neillo</a>. Among the common traditional Malay items usually made of silver includes pillow ends, belt buckles, matt corners, stoppers for water vessels, Keris sheaths and tobacco boxes. The "Awan Larat" (cloud patterns) and "Kerawang" (Vegetal motives) are among the popular designs for Malay decorative silver pillow ends and tobacco boxes.
The usage of brassware transcends a plethora of classical Malay social classes, being used by the members of nobility and commoners alike. The popularity of brassware is heavily contributed due to its durability, quality and affordability to all. The brassware can be narrowed into two distinctions, yellow brass for functional items and white for <a href="Ornamental%20brassware">decorative purposes</a>. It is often meticulously hammered and craved with various decorative designs in <a href="Islamic%20arts">religious</a> and floral motives. The usage of brass however, is best known for <a href="Tepak%20Sireh">Tepak Sireh</a>, a ceremonial tray for betel quid and for constructing certain musical instruments such as <a href="Gong">Gong</a>s for the classical Malay <a href="Gamelan">Gamelan</a> orchestra. Additionally, other prominent traditional Malay items made from metal includes flower vases, perfume sprinkles, serving trays, cooking pots, kettle and incense burners.
Weaponry.
The <a href="Keris">Keris</a> is one of the most revered items of Malay weaponry. Originally developed by the <a href="Javanese%20people">Javanese</a> down south, the armament gradually assumed a Malay identity after entering the <a href="Srivijaya">Srivijaya</a>n court, giving rise to characteristics distinct from its Javanese Keris forebears. By the time of <a href="Sultanate%20of%20Malacca">Malacca</a> in the 15th century, the evolution of the Malay Keris was perfected and possession of a Keris came to be regarded as part-and-parcel of Malay culture, becoming a philosophical symbol, juxtapositioned in prestige, craftsmanship, masculinity and honour.
During the classical era, a Malay man was not seen without a Keris outside of his house. The absence of a Keris on a man was frowned upon, perceived as if he were parading naked to the public. Traditionally, a man of Malay extraction would own three types of Keris: "Keris Pusaka" (the Dynasty Keris, inherited from one generation to another), "Keris Pangkat" (the Status Keris, awarded in right of his position in Malay society) and "Keris Perjuangan Dirinya" (the Struggle Keris, literally defined as his personal Keris). There are many strict rules, regulations and taboos to be adhered to in owning a Keris. The blade of a Kris is usually coated in a venomous arsenic, thus crafting an excruciatingly lethal blade for its prey. Traditionally, each Keris is also regarded as possessing a <a href="Spirit%20%28animating%20force%29">spirit</a>, known as "semangat". Special rituals were to be conducted to nurture, preserve and guard the "soul" of the weapon. The spiritual approach is usually held every "Malam Jumaat" (Thursday night), with the blade is being purified with <a href="Lime%20%28fruit%29">lime</a> and smoked with <a href="incense">incense</a>, dedicated prayers and devoted mantras would be also recited upon to complement the mystic ritual.
The Malays and Javanese are abided by contrasting philosophical <a href="values">values</a> pertaining to Keris-wearing. Traditionally, a Malay would embedded his Keris from the front, an honour that the weapon is more paramount compared to the wearer and a constant reminder that one is always equipped to combat the nemesis. The Javanese however, adhered to the principle that he should be more cautious and the Keris may solely be exercised during the time of need, thus cladding their Keris from behind. The Javanese also believed that by mobilising their weapon that position, it would confused the enemy.
Paradoxically, both groups shared a similar ideology addressing the <a href="Kris%23Hilt">hilt</a> of the Keris. If the hilt faced up front, it serves as a testament that the man is prepared for a fight. Nevertheless, if the hilt is turned behind, it is an oath that the person is embracing for a <a href="Conflict%20resolution">reconciliation</a>.
There are also a plethora of other forms of weaponry in the Malay arsenal, all were nevertheless equally revered in a correlating manner as the Keris. The Malays would classified the traditional weapons under 7 different structures: "Tuju" ("Direct", the large and heavy artillery, including the Malay <a href="cannons">cannons</a> of "Meriam", "<a href="Ekor%20lotong">Ekor Lontong</a>", "<a href="Lela%20%28cannon%29">Lela</a>" and "<a href="Rentaka">Rentaka</a>"), "Bidik" ("<a href="Gun">Gun</a>", a weapon with metal tube propelled by an <a href="ammunition">ammunition</a>, with the Malay forms of "<a href="Dragon%20%28firearm%29">Terakor</a>" and "Istingar"), "Setubuh" ("A body", weapon in the similar dimension of a <a href="human%20body">human body</a>, referred to the Malay <a href="spears">spears</a> of "Tongkat Panjang" and "Lembing"), "Selengan" ("An arm", a large <a href="saber">saber</a> from the length of the shoulders to the tips of the fingers, constituting the Malay saber of "Pedang" and "<a href="Sundang">Sundang</a>"), "Setangan" ("A hand", a sword with the diameter measured from the elbow to the 3 fingers, including "Badik Panjang" and "Tekpi"), "Sepegang" ("A hold", smaller than the "Setangan", a <a href="dagger">dagger</a> with "Keris" and "Badik" in the category) and "Segenggam" ("A grab", the smallest in the category, the hand-sized <a href="blade">blade</a>, including "Lawi Ayam", "<a href="Kerambit">Kerambit</a>", "Kuku Macan" and "Kapak Binjai"). Other items in the traditional Malay weaponry includes "sumpit" (<a href="Blowgun">Blowpipe</a>) and "Busur dan Panah" (<a href="Bow%20and%20Arrow">Bow and Arrow</a>), which are distinct from the seven class of armaments. Additionally, the Malays also would deploy "Zirah", a type of "<a href="Baju%20Rantai">Baju Besi</a>" (<a href="armour">armour</a>) and "Perisai" (<a href="shield">shield</a>) as defense mechanisms during the <a href="armed%20conflict">armed conflict</a>.
Traditional games.
Traditional Malay games usually require craft skills and manual dexterity and can be traced their origins since the days of Malacca Sultanate. "<a href="Sepak%20Raga">Sepak Raga</a>" and <a href="kite%20flying">kite flying</a> are among traditional games that were mentioned in the <a href="Malay%20Annals">Malay Annals</a> being played by nobilities and royalties of the Malay sultanate.
"<a href="Sepak%20Raga">Sepak Raga</a>" is one of the most popular Malay games and has been played for centuries. Traditionally, Sepak raga was played in circle by kicking and keeps aloft the rattan ball using any part of the body except the arms and hands. It is now recognised as <a href="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>'s national sport and played in the international sporting events such as <a href="Asian%20Games">Asian Games</a> and <a href="Southeast%20Asian%20Games">Southeast Asian Games</a>.
Other popular game is <a href="top">"Gasing" spinning</a> which usually played after the <a href="harvest">harvest</a> season. A great skill of <a href="Artisan">craftsmanship</a> is required to produce the most competitive "Gasing" (top), some of which spin for two hours at a time.
Possibly the most popular Malay games is the "<a href="Wau%20bulan">Wau</a>" (a unique kind of kite from east coast of Malay peninsular) or kite flying. Wau-flying competitions take place with judges awarding points for craftsmanship ("Wau" are beautiful, colourful objects set on bamboo frames), sound (all <a href="Malay%20kite">Malay kite</a>s are designed to create a specific sound as they are buffeted about in the wind) and altitude.
The Malays also have a variant of <a href="Mancala">Mancala</a> board game known as <a href="Congkak">Congkak</a>. The game is played by moving stones, marbles, beads or shells around a wooden board consisting of twelve or more holes. Mancala is acknowledged as the oldest game in the world and can be traced its origin since <a href="Ancient%20Egypt">Ancient Egypt</a>.
As the game dispersed around the globe, every culture has invented its own variation including the Malays.
Names and titles.
Malay personal names are complex, reflecting the hierarchical nature of the society, and titles are considered important. It has undergone tremendous change, evolving with the times to reflect the different influences that the Malays been subjected over the ages. Although some Malay names still retain parts of its indigenous <a href="Malay%20language">Malay</a> and <a href="Sanskrit%20language">Sanskrit</a> influences, as Muslims, Malays have long favoured <a href="Arabic%20names">Arabic names</a> as marks of their religion.
Malay names are <a href="patronymic">patronymic</a> and can be consisted of up to four parts; a title, a given name, the family name, and a description of the individual's male parentage. Some given names and father's names can be composed of double names and even triple names, therefore generating a longer name. For example, one of the Malaysian national footballer has the full name <a href="Mohd%20Zaquan%20Adha%20Abdul%20Radzak">Mohd Zaquan Adha Abdul Radzak</a>, where 'Mohd Zaquan Adha' is his triple given name and 'Abdul Radzak' is his father's double given name.
In addition to naming system, the <a href="Malay%20language">Malay language</a> also has an elaborate system of <a href="titles">titles</a> and <a href="honorifics">honorifics</a>, which are still extensively used in <a href="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> and <a href="Brunei">Brunei</a>. By applying these <a href="Malay%20titles">Malay titles</a> to a normal Malay name, a more complex name is produced. The former <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Malaysia">Prime Minister of Malaysia</a> has the full name <a href="Najib%20Tun%20Razak">Dato' Seri Mohd Najib bin Tun Haji Abdul Razak</a>, where 'Dato' Seri' is a Malay title of honour, 'Mohd Najib' is his personal name, 'bin' is derived from an Arabic word Ibnu meaning "son of" if in case of daughter it is replaced with binti, an Arabic word "bintun" meaning "daughter of", introduces his father's titles and names, 'Tun' is a higher honour, 'Haji' denotes his father's <a href="Hajj">Hajj</a> pilgrimage to <a href="Mecca">Mecca</a>, and 'Abdul Razak' is his father's personal name.
The more extremely complex Malay names however, belong to the Malay royalties. The reigning <a href="Yang%20di-Pertuan%20Agong">Yang di-Pertuan Agong</a> of <a href="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> has the full regnal name <a href="Abdullah%20of%20Pahang">Kebawah Duli Yang Maha Mulia Seri Paduka Baginda Yang di-Pertuan Agong Al-Sultan Abdullah Ri'ayatuddin Al-Mustafa Billah Shah ibni Almarhum Sultan Haji Ahmad Shah Al-Musta'in Billah</a>, while the reigning <a href="Sultan%20of%20Brunei">Sultan of Brunei</a> officially known as <a href="Hassanal%20Bolkiah">Kebawah Duli Yang Maha Mulia Paduka Seri Baginda Sultan Haji Hassanal Bolkiah Mu'izzaddin Waddaulah ibni Al-Marhum Sultan Haji Omar 'Ali Saifuddien Sa'adul Khairi Waddien</a>.
Sub-ethnic groups.
Although only constituting 3.4% of the total population, ethnic Malays are one of the most widely distributed ethnicities in Indonesia. As shown on the map, outside the <a href="Indonesian%20archipelago">Indonesian archipelago</a>, the Malay people inhabit the <a href="Malay%20Peninsula">Malay Peninsula</a>, forming the dominant ethnic group in peninsular Malaysia and a significant minority in <a href="Singapore">Singapore</a>, Thailand and southern Myanmar. The corridor of <a href="Bornean">Bornean</a> Malay territories begins north from southwestern <a href="Sabah">Sabah</a>, continues with the country of <a href="Brunei%20Darussalam">Brunei Darussalam</a>, coastal <a href="Sarawak">Sarawak</a> and continues down to <a href="Kalimantan">Kalimantan</a>. Other areas with a significant centuries-old Malay communities outside the map includes <a href="Bangkok">Bangkok</a>, Thailand; <a href="Mecca">Mecca</a>, Saudi Arabia; <a href="Christmas%20Island">Christmas</a> and <a href="Cocos%20Islands">Cocos Islands</a> (Australia); a large diaspora community in <a href="Sri%20Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>; and <a href="Cape%20Malays">Cape Malays</a> of South Africa, although the latter two are predominantly of creoled origin from the Malay Archipelago bought by the Dutch and the British.
The Korinchi Malays have their origins in Sumatra, but small numbers live across the peninsula today. They were reputed to have the ability to transform from a man into a "<a href="werecat">were-tiger</a>".
